Implement the following plan:

# Plan: Integrate Skeleton UI into pdfwasm

## Context

The project currently uses hand-written scoped CSS with hardcoded colors. We want to bring in **Skeleton v4** (skeleton.dev) as the UI component library to get a polished, themeable design system with dark mode support. Skeleton is built on Tailwind CSS 4 and provides both Tailwind utility classes and pre-built Svelte components.

## Step 1: Install dependencies

```bash
pnpm add -D @skeletonlabs/skeleton @skeletonlabs/skeleton-svelte tailwindcss
```

Skeleton v4 requires: SvelteKit 2+ (have it), Svelte 5+ (have it), Tailwind 4+.

## Step 2: Create global stylesheet with Skeleton imports

Replace `src/app.css` content with:

```css
@import 'tailwindcss';
@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton';
@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton-svelte';
@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton/themes/rocket';
```

This sets up Tailwind 4 + Skeleton's design tokens + the `rocket` theme.

## Step 3: Add theme attribute to `app.html`

Update `<html lang="en">` to `<html lang="en" data-theme="rocket">`.

## Step 4: Migrate `+page.svelte` toolbar

Replace hand-written toolbar with Skeleton components:
- **AppBar** for the top toolbar (title + buttons)
- Skeleton button classes (`btn preset-filled`) for "Open PDF" and "Split Mode"
- Use Skeleton's text/color utilities for status/error messages

## Step 5: Migrate `SearchBar.svelte`

- Use Skeleton's form input classes for the search input
- Use Skeleton's button/chip classes for the toggle buttons (Aa, W)
- Use Skeleton's badge or text styles for match count
- Navigation buttons (↑↓) use Skeleton button variants

## Step 6: Migrate `PdfViewer.svelte` split toolbar

- Use Skeleton's Slider component or styled range input
- Export button uses Skeleton button preset classes
- Split info text uses Skeleton typography utilities

## Step 7: Remove old scoped CSS

As each component is migrated, remove the `<style>` blocks that are replaced by Tailwind utility classes and Skeleton component classes. Keep any layout-specific CSS that isn't covered by Skeleton (e.g., canvas overlay positioning, split grid layout).

## Files to modify

1. `package.json` — new dependencies (via pnpm)
2. `src/app.css` — replace with Skeleton/Tailwind imports
3. `src/app.html` — add `data-theme`
4. `src/routes/+page.svelte` — toolbar → AppBar + Skeleton classes
5. `src/lib/components/SearchBar.svelte` — inputs/buttons → Skeleton classes
6. `src/lib/components/PdfViewer.svelte` — split toolbar → Skeleton classes

Files NOT modified (no UI changes needed):
- `src/lib/components/PdfPage.svelte` — canvas rendering, keep as-is
- `src/lib/services/*` — business logic, untouched

## Verification

1. `pnpm run dev` — dev server starts without errors
2. `pnpm run check` — TypeScript/Svelte check passes
3. Visual check: theme applied, toolbar styled, search bar functional, split mode works
4. Dark mode toggle test (if applicable via theme)


If you need specific details from before exiting plan mode (like exact code snippets, error messages, or content you generated), read the full transcript at: /Users/daishokomiyama/.REDACTED.jsonl

planContent:
# Plan: Integrate Skeleton UI into pdfwasm

## Context

The project currently uses hand-written scoped CSS with hardcoded colors. We want to bring in **Skeleton v4** (skeleton.dev) as the UI component library to get a polished, themeable design system with dark mode support. Skeleton is built on Tailwind CSS 4 and provides both Tailwind utility classes and pre-built Svelte components.

## Step 1: Install dependencies

```bash
pnpm add -D @skeletonlabs/skeleton @skeletonlabs/skeleton-svelte tailwindcss
```

Skeleton v4 requires: SvelteKit 2+ (have it), Svelte 5+ (have it), Tailwind 4+.

## Step 2: Create global stylesheet with Skeleton imports

Replace `src/app.css` content with:

```css
@import 'tailwindcss';
@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton';
@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton-svelte';
@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton/themes/rocket';
```

This sets up Tailwind 4 + Skeleton's design tokens + the `rocket` theme.

## Step 3: Add theme attribute to `app.html`

Update `<html lang="en">` to `<html lang="en" data-theme="rocket">`.

## Step 4: Migrate `+page.svelte` toolbar

Replace hand-written toolbar with Skeleton components:
- **AppBar** for the top toolbar (title + buttons)
- Skeleton button classes (`btn preset-filled`) for "Open PDF" and "Split Mode"
- Use Skeleton's text/color utilities for status/error messages

## Step 5: Migrate `SearchBar.svelte`

- Use Skeleton's form input classes for the search input
- Use Skeleton's button/chip classes for the toggle buttons (Aa, W)
- Use Skeleton's badge or text styles for match count
- Navigation buttons (↑↓) use Skeleton button variants

## Step 6: Migrate `PdfViewer.svelte` split toolbar

- Use Skeleton's Slider component or styled range input
- Export button uses Skeleton button preset classes
- Split info text uses Skeleton typography utilities

## Step 7: Remove old scoped CSS

As each component is migrated, remove the `<style>` blocks that are replaced by Tailwind utility classes and Skeleton component classes. Keep any layout-specific CSS that isn't covered by Skeleton (e.g., canvas overlay positioning, split grid layout).

## Files to modify

1. `package.json` — new dependencies (via pnpm)
2. `src/app.css` — replace with Skeleton/Tailwind imports
3. `src/app.html` — add `data-theme`
4. `src/routes/+page.svelte` — toolbar → AppBar + Skeleton classes
5. `src/lib/components/SearchBar.svelte` — inputs/buttons → Skeleton classes
6. `src/lib/components/PdfViewer.svelte` — split toolbar → Skeleton classes

Files NOT modified (no UI changes needed):
- `src/lib/components/PdfPage.svelte` — canvas rendering, keep as-is
- `src/lib/services/*` — business logic, untouched

## Verification

1. `pnpm run dev` — dev server starts without errors
2. `pnpm run check` — TypeScript/Svelte check passes
3. Visual check: theme applied, toolbar styled, search bar functional, split mode works
4. Dark mode toggle test (if applicable via theme)

Based on the search results, here's information about setting up Skeleton v4 with Svelte, Tailwind CSS 4, and app.css imports:

## Key Setup Information

Install the Skeleton core and Svelte component packages, then in your app.css file add imports for: `@import 'tailwindcss'`, `@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton'`, `@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton-svelte'`, and a theme like `@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton/themes/cerberus'`.

## Tailwind v4 Configuration Changes

The tailwind.config file has been removed in favor of CSS-based configuration in your global stylesheet. You should rename your app.postcss or app.pcss to app.css.

## Other Important Changes

- The Skeleton data-theme attribute has moved from `<body>` to `<html>`
- You are still required to implement the Tailwind Forms Plugin to use Skeleton form elements
- Skeleton is building select portions using Sass to handle the transition to Tailwind v4's CSS-based configuration, though Sass is only used by maintainers of Skeleton and will not be a dependency for end users

For detailed migration guidance, Skeleton provides a dedicated migration script as part of the Skeleton CLI to help automate much of this process.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.content:
# Skeleton UI Installation for SvelteKit

## Installation Commands

```bash
npx sv create --types ts my-skeleton-app
cd my-skeleton-app
npm i -D @skeletonlabs/skeleton @skeletonlabs/skeleton-svelte
```

> **Note:** If Tailwind wasn't selected during project creation, run `npx sv add tailwindcss` first.

## CSS Configuration

Add these imports to `/src/routes/layout.css`:

```css
@import 'tailwindcss';

@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton'; 
@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton-svelte'; 
@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton/themes/cerberus';
```

## HTML Setup

In `/src/app.html`, set the theme via the `data-theme` attribute:

```html
<html data-theme="cerberus">
    <!-- ... -->
</html>
```

## Start Development

```bash
npm run dev
```

## Requirements

- SvelteKit 2+
- Svelte 5+
- Tailwind CSS 4+

Based on the search results, here's information about the Skeleton.dev v4 AppBar component for Svelte: ## Import Usage For Skeleton v4 with Svelte, you import AppBar from '@skeletonlabs/skeleton-svelte': ```typescript ``` ## Component Structure The AppBar component is structured with a root AppBar element containing an AppBar.Toolbar with child components: AppBar.Lead, AppBar.Headline, and AppBar.Trail: ```svelte ``` ## Snippet-Based API The v4 AppBar uses Svelte snippets with lead(), trail(), and headline() snippet functions instead of slot-based components. Here's an example using this approach: ```svelte {#snippet lead()} {/snippet} {#snippet trail()} {/snippet} {#snippet headline()}

Headline

{/snippet} ``` The AppBar is described as a header element for the top of your page layout.

content.content:
# Skeleton v4 Button, Input, Badge & Form Classes

Based on the Fundamentals documentation provided, here's what's available in Skeleton v4:

## Button Classes
The documentation mentions "Provide a variety of button, including customizable sizes and types" but doesn't list specific class names in the Fundamentals page.

## Presets & Utility Classes
Skeleton uses a **preset system** for styling components. The docs reference "Canned styles for your interface elements" through the Presets section, though specific preset names aren't detailed in this excerpt.

## Available Component Categories
The documentation covers styling approaches for:

- **Buttons** - customizable sizes and types
- **Badges** - non-interactive badge styles
- **Chips** - interactive chip styles  
- **Forms and Inputs** - various form and input styles

## Styling Method
Components accept CSS utility classes via the `className` (React) or `class` (Svelte) attribute: "Use this to pass any CSS utility class."

**To find specific class names and presets**, you'll need to visit the individual component documentation pages linked in the Fundamentals guide (Badges, Buttons, Forms and Inputs sections) rather than this overview page.

# Badge CSS Class Names

Based on the documentation, the exact CSS class names for badges are:

- **`.badge`** - Standard badge container
- **`.badge-icon`** - For icon-only badges or overlapping badges

These base classes are combined with preset modifiers like:
- `.preset-filled-primary-500`
- `.preset-tonal-primary`
- `.preset-outlined-primary-500`

**Note:** The page covers badges specifically. For chips, you would need to reference the "[Chips](/docs/svelte/tailwind-components/chips "Chips")" documentation section, which isn't detailed in the content provided.

content.content:
# Form Element CSS Classes in Skeleton UI

Based on the documentation, here are the exact class names:

**Basic Form Elements:**
- `"input"` - for text inputs and various input types
- `"select"` - for dropdown selections
- `"textarea"` - for multi-line text areas
- `"checkbox"` - for checkbox inputs
- `"radio"` - for radio button inputs
- `"progress"` - for progress bars

**Form Labels & Structure:**
- `"label"` - wraps form fields
- `"label-text"` - styles the label text

**Input Groups (composite elements):**
- `"input-group"` - parent container
- `"ig-cell"` - child cell for text/icons
- `"ig-input"` - child input element
- `"ig-select"` - child select element
- `"ig-btn"` - child button

The documentation notes that Skeleton relies on the `@tailwindcss/forms` plugin to normalize form styling, which is a required prerequisite for these utilities to function properly.

content.content:
# Skeleton UI Button CSS Classes

Based on the documentation, here are the button variants:

## Core Classes
- `btn` - standard button
- `btn-icon` - icon-only button
- `btn-group` - grouped buttons container
- `btn-sm`, `btn-base`, `btn-lg` - size modifiers

## Preset Styles (Filled/Tonal/Outlined)
The system supports three style patterns across seven color options:

**Filled:** `preset-filled-primary-500`, `preset-filled-secondary-500`, `preset-filled-tertiary-500`, `preset-filled-success-500`, `preset-filled-warning-500`, `preset-filled-error-500`, `preset-filled-surface-500`

**Tonal:** `preset-tonal-primary`, `preset-tonal-secondary`, `preset-tonal-tertiary`, `preset-tonal-success`, `preset-tonal-warning`, `preset-tonal-error`, `preset-tonal-surface`

**Outlined:** `preset-outlined-primary-500`, `preset-outlined-secondary-500`, `preset-outlined-tertiary-500`, `preset-outlined-success-500`, `preset-outlined-warning-500`, `preset-outlined-error-500`, `preset-outlined-surface-500`

## Additional Modifiers
- `disabled` - HTML attribute for disabled state
- `bg-surface-50-950` - background color utility
- Gradient utilities like `bg-linear-to-br from-primary-500 to-secondary-500`

content.text:
Perfect! Now I have all the information. Let me compile a comprehensive summary of the Skeleton v4 CSS class names.

## Skeleton v4 CSS Class Names Summary

Based on the official documentation and the installed `@skeletonlabs/skeleton` v4 package, here are the exact CSS class names:

### Button Classes

**Base Classes:**
- `btn` - Standard button
- `btn-icon` - Icon-only button
- `btn-group` - Grouped buttons container

**Button Sizes:**
- `btn-sm` - Small button (text-xs)
- `btn-base` - Base/default size (text-base)
- `btn-lg` - Large button (text-xl)

**Icon Button Sizes:**
- `btn-icon-sm` - Small icon button
- `btn-icon-base` - Base/default icon button
- `btn-icon-lg` - Large icon button

**Button Preset Styles (Filled):**
- `preset-filled` - Default filled style
- `preset-filled-primary-500`, `preset-filled-primary-50-950`, `preset-filled-primary-100-900`, etc.
- `preset-filled-secondary-500`, `preset-filled-secondary-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-filled-tertiary-500`, `preset-filled-tertiary-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-filled-success-500`, `preset-filled-success-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-filled-warning-500`, `preset-filled-warning-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-filled-error-500`, `preset-filled-error-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-filled-surface-500`, `preset-filled-surface-50-950`, etc.

**Button Preset Styles (Tonal):**
- `preset-tonal` - Default tonal style
- `preset-tonal-primary`
- `preset-tonal-secondary`
- `preset-tonal-tertiary`
- `preset-tonal-success`
- `preset-tonal-warning`
- `preset-tonal-error`
- `preset-tonal-surface`

**Button Preset Styles (Outlined):**
- `preset-outlined` - Default outlined style
- `preset-outlined-primary-500`, `preset-outlined-primary-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-outlined-secondary-500`, `preset-outlined-secondary-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-outlined-tertiary-500`, `preset-outlined-tertiary-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-outlined-success-500`, `preset-outlined-success-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-outlined-warning-500`, `preset-outlined-warning-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-outlined-error-500`, `preset-outlined-error-50-950`, etc.
- `preset-outlined-surface-500`, `preset-outlined-surface-50-950`, etc.

### Form Input Classes

**Basic Form Elements:**
- `input` - Text input and input types (file, range, color)
- `select` - Dropdown select element
- `textarea` - Multi-line text area
- `checkbox` - Checkbox input
- `radio` - Radio button input
- `progress` - Progress bar

**Form Labels & Structure:**
- `label` - Label wrapper container
- `label-text` - Styled label text
- `fieldset` - Fieldset container
- `legend` - Legend element

**Input Group Classes:**
- `input-group` - Parent container for grouped form elements
- `ig-cell` - Cell for text/icons in input group
- `ig-input` - Input element within input group
- `ig-select` - Select element within input group
- `ig-btn` - Button element within input group

**Special Input Styles:**
- `input-ghost` - Transparent input (used for TagsInput component)

### Badge Classes

**Base Classes:**
- `badge` - Standard badge container
- `badge-icon` - Icon-only badge or overlapping badges

**Badge Preset Styles:**
Badges support the same preset modifiers as buttons:
- `preset-filled-[color]-[shade]`
- `preset-tonal-[color]`
- `preset-outlined-[color]-[shade]`

Color options: `primary`, `secondary`, `tertiary`, `success`, `warning`, `error`, `surface`

### Chip Classes

**Base Classes:**
- `chip` - Standard chip container
- `chip-icon` - Icon-only chip or icon within chip

**Chip Preset Styles:**
Chips support the same preset modifiers as buttons and badges:
- `preset-filled-[color]-[shade]`
- `preset-tonal-[color]`
- `preset-outlined-[color]-[shade]`

### Additional Utility Classes

**Color Variations:**
For filled presets, common shade variations are:
- `-50-950`, `-100-900`, `-200-800`, `-300-700`, `-400-600`, `-500`, `-600-400`, `-700-300`, `-800-200`, `-900-100`, `-950-50`

**Common Combinations:**
- `preset-filled-primary-500` + `btn`
- `preset-tonal-secondary` + `badge`
- `preset-outlined-error-500` + `chip`

All interactive elements (buttons, inputs, badges, chips) respond to:
- `:hover` - Brightness adjustment
- `:focus` / `:focus-within` - Primary color ring
- `:disabled` - Disabled state

All done. Here's a summary of what was implemented:

**Dependencies installed:**
- `@skeletonlabs/skeleton` 4.12.0

**Files modified:**

1. **`src/app.css`** — Replaced hand-written reset CSS with Tailwind 4 + Skeleton imports + `rocket` theme
2. **`src/app.html`** — Added `data-theme="rocket"` to `<html>` tag
3. **`src/routes/+page.svelte`** — Replaced custom toolbar with `AppBar` compound component (`AppBar > AppBar.Toolbar > AppBar.Lead / AppBar.Trail`), buttons use `btn preset-filled` classes, removed entire `<style>` block
4. **`src/lib/components/SearchBar.svelte`** — Replaced all scoped CSS with Skeleton utility classes (`input`, `btn-icon`, `preset-filled`, `preset-tonal-surface`), removed entire `<style>` block
5. **`src/lib/components/PdfViewer.svelte`** — Split toolbar uses Skeleton classes (`btn btn-sm preset-filled-success-500`, warning color tokens for background), kept layout-specific CSS (split grid, thumbnail scaling, split dividers) but converted hardcoded colors to Skeleton CSS custom properties (`--color-surface-300`, `--color-primary-500`, `--color-error-500`)

**Verification:** `pnpm run check` passes with 0 errors, dev server starts cleanly.

The `@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton-svelte'` is resolving to the JS entry point, not a CSS file. That import is only needed as a JS import in Svelte components — it shouldn't be in the CSS file. Let me check what CSS imports are actually needed.

content.text: The issue is that `<label>` doesn't get styled by Skeleton's `.btn` class the same way `<button>` does. The `btn` class targets actual `<button>` elements. Let me check what Skeleton's button CSS actually matches.

The `btn` utility is purely CSS — it applies to any element with the class. So that's fine. The problem is likely that the `preset-filled` class needs the Tailwind `@source` to detect it. Since we're applying these classes dynamically, Tailwind 4's JIT might not be scanning them properly.

Let me check the presets CSS to understand how they work.

The utilities are defined via `@utility` — these are Tailwind v4 custom utilities that get registered through the `@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton'`. The issue might be that Tailwind 4 isn't scanning our Svelte files for class names. Let me check if there's an `@source` directive needed.

I've found comprehensive information about installing Tailwind CSS v4 with the @tailwindcss/vite plugin in SvelteKit. Here are the key steps:

## Installation Steps

### 1. Install Dependencies
Install tailwindcss and @tailwindcss/vite via npm:
```bash
npm install tailwindcss @tailwindcss/vite
```

### 2. Configure Vite
Add the @tailwindcss/vite plugin to your vite.config.ts file:
```typescript
import { sveltekit } from '@sveltejs/kit/vite';
import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import tailwindcss from '@tailwindcss/vite';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [
    tailwindcss(),
    sveltekit(),
  ],
});
```

### 3. Create CSS File
Create a ./src/app.css file and add an @import that imports Tailwind CSS.

### 4. Import in Layout
Create a ./src/routes/+layout.svelte file and import the newly-created app.css file.

### 5. Start Development
Run your build process with npm run dev.

## Alternative: Using SvelteKit CLI
You can also use the SvelteKit CLI for easier setup: use `npx sv add tailwindcss` for Tailwind setup following the Tailwind for SvelteKit guide with Tailwind Vite plugin.

The @tailwindcss/vite plugin is the modern approach for Tailwind CSS v4 with SvelteKit, replacing the older PostCSS configuration method.

content.text: Dev server starts cleanly, type check passes with 0 errors. The fix was adding the `@tailwindcss/vite` plugin — without it, Tailwind 4 wasn't processing the CSS at all, so `btn`, `preset-filled`, and all other utility classes were being ignored. The buttons should now render properly with Skeleton's filled preset styling.

message.content: tailwindcss will tree-shake with my setup?

content.thinking: The user is asking whether Tailwind CSS will properly tree-shake (purge unused styles) with their current setup. This is a question about the current configuration, not a new implementation task. Let me investigate.

content.text: Good question. Let me check the current setup to verify.

Yes, it will tree-shake. Here's why:

**Tailwind v4 with `@tailwindcss/vite`** automatically scans your source files for class usage and only emits CSS for classes it finds. This is built-in — no `content` config needed like in v3.

The `@utility` directives from Skeleton (like `btn`, `preset-filled`, etc.) are **registered** by the `@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton'`, but only **included in the output** if Tailwind detects them in your `.svelte`/`.ts` files. Same for standard Tailwind utilities like `flex`, `items-center`, etc.

One caveat: **dynamic class names** like this in `+page.svelte`:

```svelte
class="btn {splitMode ? 'preset-filled-error-500' : 'preset-filled'}"
```

These work fine because Tailwind v4 scans for string literals — it sees both `preset-filled-error-500` and `preset-filled` as static strings in the source. You'd only lose tree-shaking if you did something like `` class={`preset-filled-${color}`} `` with a runtime variable for the class suffix.

So your current setup is correct — no changes needed.

message.content: what do you mean by "You'd only lose tree-shaking"? Would I lose the classname in prod?

content.text:
Yes, exactly. If you constructed a class name dynamically like `` `preset-filled-${color}` ``, Tailwind would never see the full string `preset-filled-error-500` in your source code, so it would **not generate that CSS rule** in the production build. The class would be applied to the DOM element but have no corresponding styles — it would silently do nothing.

The current code is safe because both class names appear as complete string literals in the source.

message.content: i see `<header data-scope="app-bar" data-part="root">`, who inserts data-scope: app-bar and data-part: root? Skeleton?

content.text:
Yes, Skeleton's Svelte components insert those attributes. They use a data-attribute convention (`data-scope`, `data-part`) to scope their internal CSS and identify component anatomy. For example, `AppBar` sets `data-scope="app-bar"` on the root `<header>`, `AppBar.Toolbar` sets `data-part="toolbar"`, `AppBar.Lead` sets `data-part="lead"`, etc.

This is how Skeleton targets its own component styles without relying on class names — their component CSS uses selectors like `[data-scope="app-bar"][data-part="root"]` internally.

content.text:
Excellent! Now I have all the information I need. Let me compile a comprehensive report for the user.

## Skeleton UI Theme Exploration Report

### 1. All Available Themes (22 total)

1. **catppuccin** - Pastel, rounded aesthetic (colorful)
2. **cerberus** - Three-colored guardian aesthetic (colorful)
3. **concord** - Harmonious color palette
4. **crimson** - Red-focused theme
5. **fennec** - Warm desert colors
6. **hamlindigo** - Indigo-focused theme
7. **legacy** - Classic styling
8. **mint** - Cool mint green theme
9. **modern** - Contemporary design
10. **mona** - Mona Lisa inspired palette
11. **nosh** - Casual comfort aesthetic
12. **nouveau** - Art nouveau styling
13. **pine** - Forest green palette
14. **reign** - Royal color scheme
15. **rocket** - Sleek modern theme (the most minimal/neutral)
16. **rose** - Pink and rose tones (colorful)
17. **sahara** - Desert-inspired palette
18. **seafoam** - Ocean spray colors
19. **terminus** - Terminal/technical aesthetic
20. **vintage** - Retro styling
21. **vox** - Voice/communication theme
22. **wintry** - Cool winter colors

---

### 2. Key Color Tokens Comparison

#### **Rocket Theme** (most neutral/minimal)
Uses OKLCH color space with very subtle hue variations. Primarily leverages lightness and saturation:
- **Primary:** Blues (210-215 degrees) - `oklch(71.48% 0.13 215.21deg)` at 500
- **Secondary:** Purples (259 degrees) - `oklch(62.31% 0.19 259.81deg)` at 500
- **Tertiary:** Pinks (304 degrees) - `oklch(62.68% 0.23 303.91deg)` at 500
- **Surface:** Nearly neutral grays with barely perceptible hue
- **Typography:** Uses `system-ui, sans-serif` condensed heading font

#### **Catppuccin Theme** (colorful - pastel, rounded)
Softer, more rounded aesthetic with warmer saturation:
- **Primary:** Blue-purple (273 degrees) - `oklch(66.37% 0.18 273.14deg)` at 500
- **Secondary:** Pinks/Reds (338 degrees) - `oklch(72.56% 0.17 338.45deg)` at 500 (higher saturation!)
- **Tertiary:** Cyans/Teals (201 degrees) - `oklch(60.23% 0.1 201.09deg)` at 500
- **Error:** Vibrant reds (`oklch(55.05% 0.22 19.81deg)` at 500) - much more saturated
- **Typography:** Rounded UI font family (`ui-rounded`, `Quicksand`, `Comfortaa`)
- **Heading color:** Tertiary color instead of inherit (tertiary at 500, 200 in dark mode)

#### **Cerberus Theme** (colorful - bold three-color)
Very bold and saturated, "three-headed guard" concept:
- **Primary:** Blues (257-258 degrees) - `oklch(0.57 0.21 258.29)` - **HIGH saturation 0.21!**
- **Secondary:** Magentas/Purples (300 degrees) - `oklch(0.49 0.23 300.45)` - **HIGHEST saturation 0.23!**
- **Tertiary:** Reds (2.47 degrees) - `oklch(0.65 0.26 2.47)` - **EXTREMELY vibrant red!**
- **Surface:** Pure grayscale (0 saturation) - elegant contrast
- **Typography:** Bold heading weight instead of normal
- **Border radius:** 0.25rem (sharper edges than rocket's 0.375rem)

#### **Rose Theme** (colorful - elegant pinks)
Warm rose/pink palette with serif sophistication:
- **Primary:** Rose/Pink (346 degrees) - `oklch(69.89% 0.13 348.12deg)` at 500
- **Secondary:** Purple/Mauve (272 degrees) - `oklch(46.75% 0.22 272.16deg)` at 500 - **vibrant!**
- **Tertiary:** Warm peach (34 degrees) - lower saturation
- **Typography:** Serif font (`Seravek`, `Gill Sans Nova`) with 0.025em letter-spacing for elegance
- **Heading colors:** Uses secondary colors (900 light / 100 dark)

---

### 3. How Theme Customization Works

**CSS Custom Properties (CSS Variables):**
Skeleton themes are built entirely on **CSS custom properties** defined in a `@theme` block. Themes work through:

1. **Data Attribute Selection:**
   - Applied via `[data-theme='theme-name']` attribute on HTML element
   - Example: `<html data-theme="rocket">`

2. **CSS Custom Variants (Tailwind):**
   - Each theme gets a custom variant in `/src/variants/themes.css`
   - Example: `@custom-variant theme-rocket (&:where([data-theme="rocket"] *));`
   - Allows conditional Tailwind utilities: `text-theme-rocket:text-primary-500`

3. **Token Categories:**
   Each theme defines:
   - **Typography:** font family, color, weight, size, scaling
   - **Colors:** Primary, Secondary, Tertiary, Success, Warning, Error, Surface (each with 50-950 shades)
   - **Contrast colors:** Auto-detected dark/light pairs for accessibility
   - **Spacing & Borders:** radius, border widths
   - **Background:** body background (light/dark modes)

4. **Import Method:**
   Themes are exported from the package as standalone CSS files:
   ```
   import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton/themes/rocket.css'
   import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton/themes/catppuccin.css'
   ```

5. **Custom Theme Creation:**
   You can create custom themes by:
   - Creating a new `.css` file with `[data-theme='custom-name']` selector
   - Defining all required CSS variables (see `base/theme.css` for the full list)
   - Using OKLCH color space (modern, perceptually uniform)
   - Including primary, secondary, tertiary color scales (50, 100, 200...950)
   - Setting contrast color pairs for each scale
   - Including typography and spacing tokens

6. **Runtime Switching:**
   Change theme dynamically:
   ```javascript
   document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', 'cerberus')
   ```

---

### Key Differences Summary

| Aspect | Rocket | Catppuccin | Cerberus | Rose |
|--------|--------|-----------|----------|------|
| **Saturation** | Very low | Medium | Very High | Medium-High |
| **Vibe** | Minimal/Technical | Pastel/Playful | Bold/Guard | Elegant/Warm |
| **Primary Hue** | 215° (blue) | 273° (blue-purple) | 258° (blue) | 348° (pink) |
| **Font** | Condensed, System | Rounded, Friendly | Bold, System | Serif, Elegant |
| **Border Radius** | 0.375rem | 0.375rem | 0.25rem (sharp) | 0.375rem |
| **Best For** | Apps, clean UIs | Creative, playful | Bold, attention-grabbing | Elegant, premium feel |

All themes use the OKLCH color space (modern CSS standard) which provides perceptually uniform colors across different lightness levels.

6. **Runtime Switching:**
   Change theme dynamically:
   ```javascript
   document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', 'cerberus')
   ```

---

### Key Differences Summary

| Aspect | Rocket | Catppuccin | Cerberus | Rose |
|--------|--------|-----------|----------|------|
| **Saturation** | Very low | Medium | Very High | Medium-High |
| **Vibe** | Minimal/Technical | Pastel/Playful | Bold/Guard | Elegant/Warm |
| **Primary Hue** | 215° (blue) | 273° (blue-purple) | 258° (blue) | 348° (pink) |
| **Font** | Condensed, System | Rounded, Friendly | Bold, System | Serif, Elegant |
| **Border Radius** | 0.375rem | 0.375rem | 0.25rem (sharp) | 0.375rem |
| **Best For** | Apps, clean UIs | Creative, playful | Bold, attention-grabbing | Elegant, premium feel |

All themes use the OKLCH color space (modern CSS standard) which provides perceptually uniform colors across different lightness levels.

There are **22 built-in themes** — rocket is one of the most neutral/minimal ones. You have two options:

1. **Switch to a more colorful built-in theme** — e.g. `cerberus` (bold saturated blues/magentas/reds), `catppuccin` (pastel/playful with rounded fonts), `rose` (elegant pinks with serif fonts)
2. **Customize** — create your own theme CSS file with whatever colors you want, using CSS custom properties

The search results provide comprehensive information about Skeleton.dev's themes, preview colors, and generator. Here's what I found:

## Theme System Overview

Skeleton themes utilize CSS custom properties to define core settings for your design system, and are provided with a number of preset themes out of the box, as well as a powerful theme generator to create your own.

## Preset Themes

Skeleton is provided with a high quality set of hand curated themes. You can tap the theme preview to copy the theme name to your clipboard, then implement any desired theme in your app's global stylesheet.

## Theme Generator Tool

You can use the powerful Theme Generator app to create your own themes by opening the Theme Generator and customizing to your preference, making sure to set a unique name for your theme. 

The generator allows for interactive customization: Toggle the "Enable Preview" option to begin creating a new theme, and the entire documentation site will update as you progress.

## Color Configuration

You can define the palette and contrast tones as well as define background styles for light and dark mode. For those not design savvy, there's a "Randomize Colors" button to quickly generate a palette.

## Implementation

After generating your theme, you copy the source code and paste it into a new file in the root of your project with a distinct name.

content.text:
Here's how you can explore and choose:

**Browse all themes visually:** [https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/design/themes](https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/design/themes) — you can preview each theme's colors and click to copy its name.

**See the color palette for each theme:** [https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/svelte/design/colors](https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/svelte/design/colors) — shows primary, secondary, tertiary, etc. with all shades.

**Create your own:** [https://themes.skeleton.dev/](https://themes.skeleton.dev/) — an interactive theme generator where you pick colors and it outputs a CSS file you drop into your project.

To switch themes, it's just changing the import in `app.css` and the `data-theme` attribute in `app.html`. For example, switching to cerberus:

```css
@import '@skeletonlabs/skeleton/themes/cerberus';
```
```html
<html lang="en" data-theme="cerberus">
```

Want to pick a theme from those resources and I'll swap it in, or would you prefer to use the theme generator to create a custom one?

message.content: i accidentally set 'text-primary-500' to h1, and it shows a nice blue color. where does it come from? Tailwind?

content.text:
From Skeleton. The `text-primary-500` class applies `color: var(--color-primary-500)`, where `--color-primary-500` is a CSS custom property defined by the rocket theme. Rocket's primary is a blue at hue ~215° in OKLCH.

Tailwind provides the `text-{name}-{shade}` utility pattern, but the `primary` color name and its actual values come from Skeleton's theme system. Standard Tailwind only has fixed color names like `text-blue-500`, `text-red-500`, etc. — `primary`, `secondary`, `tertiary` are Skeleton's semantic color tokens injected into Tailwind's color palette.

message.content: is there a list of css class from Skeleton? i can't remember everything

content.text:
The main reference pages:

- **Buttons, badges, chips, presets:** [https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/tailwind/buttons](https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/tailwind/buttons)
- **Form inputs:** [https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/tailwind/forms](https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/tailwind/forms)
- **Typography:** [https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/tailwind/typography](https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/tailwind/typography)
- **Colors/tokens:** [https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/svelte/design/colors](https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/svelte/design/colors)
- **All components (AppBar, Accordion, etc.):** [https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/svelte/resources/contribute/components](https://www.skeleton.dev/docs/svelte/resources/contribute/components)

Quick cheat sheet from what's installed:

| Category | Classes |
|----------|---------|
| **Buttons** | `btn`, `btn-sm`, `btn-lg`, `btn-icon`, `btn-icon-sm`, `btn-icon-lg`, `btn-group` |
| **Presets** | `preset-filled`, `preset-tonal`, `preset-outlined` + color variants like `preset-filled-primary-500`, `preset-tonal-error`, etc. |
| **Badges** | `badge`, `badge-icon` + same presets |
| **Chips** | `chip`, `chip-icon` + same presets |
| **Forms** | `input`, `select`, `textarea`, `checkbox`, `radio`, `label`, `label-text`, `fieldset`, `legend` |
| **Input groups** | `input-group`, `ig-cell`, `ig-input`, `ig-select`, `ig-btn` |
| **Typography** | `h1`–`h6`, `blockquote`, `pre`, `code` |
| **Colors** | `text-primary-{50-950}`, `text-secondary-{50-950}`, `text-tertiary-{50-950}`, `text-success-{50-950}`, `text-warning-{50-950}`, `text-error-{50-950}`, `text-surface-{50-950}`, `bg-` and `border-` variants too |
